review_title: poor management and toxic environment in some depts
pros: pretty good work-life balance in terms of working hours, benefits are good if you have family/children and need some flexibility. some learning opportunities (attending courses rather than on the job growth though). tend to hear positive things about positions in faculties and profit generating depts.
cons: - poor change management within some departments (strange when they have a business improvement department within the school) - surface level attempts are made to address toxic work environments instead of implementing changes that will make a difference - senior staff who are already familiar with the loop holes will take full advantage of it, leaving junior staff to bear the brunt of work (all work, not just grunt work). for whatever work they do contribute, they will not take responsibility for anything that goes wrong. - turnover rates are high, but despite this, the management is not trying to find out what the issues are or try to fix the problem. instead, there is much dancing around "sensitive" issues or temporary fixes are implemented - which senior staff know will not affect them in the long run. senior management also protect the middle management, allowing an unhealthy cycle to continue. there are many depts and faculties - be wary of the one you are planning to join. amongst these, the alumni relations dept is one that is not recommended.

review_title: Got an offer from Office of alumni relations - Think twice before accepting
pros: SMU is a good place to work because there are many sound employee benefits. They are also practicing work from home and they do give their staff some form of empowerment to manage how they would the WFH schedule to work out. There are also many learning opportunities in the organisation for you to improve yourself. The top management are nice people and would take time to conduct frequent staff engagement sessions to know the sentiments on the ground.
cons: SMU is a big organisation with many different offices and schools. Unfortunately, some offices are wired a bit more different compared to the rest. There are obvious tell-tale signs if the office is in trouble in terms of toxic workplace culture - comb through the past job offerings and you will see which are the offices that are always hiring. These are the offices to stay away from unless you can withstand the lots of gossip mongering, bad mouthing and lots of mistrust amongst the senior staff and junior staff. The office of alumni relations is one such example of an office that is not recommended to join. There is high turnover rate and there is indeed a blatant difference in the way work is accounted for and responsibilities are upheld between the senior people in the office and the newcomers. The middle managers are essentially super good actors that would put top actors and actresses to shame are very good at putting on a good front in front of the director but at the back, start spreading terrible comments of the newcomers. There is a lot of turf guarding and self-preservation in the office. There is no growth mindset in the office and the senior staff will always gang together and try their best to not allow the junior staff to succeed. You can survive here if you can somehow break into the circle of the senior staff. The situation is so absurd that if you are within the close circle of the senior staff, you can slack on your job responsibilities and still get away with it.

review_title: Not recommended until there's positive changes to the work environment itself
pros: There are really genuinely a good handful of colleagues and Professors here that makes the cons here bearable. Their understanding nature shines through their speech and their action which makes it really helpful as the days here can be very challenging
cons:
- Constant change in processes makes it very difficult to keep up. The processes here can change on the fly without being formally informed to the team. Considered yourself lucky if you were informed about it. 
- Too many leaders but no leadership. 
- No sense of ownership or accountability within the team which makes the already confusing work place even more challenging to work in. 
- Calls are left without being put on break mode which causes it to be abandoned till it goes to the next available person. Issue was finally caught before I left the place. 
- No one actually follow up with their cases promptly therefore causing delays and complain by users and staffs. 
- No equal access to the Systems across all team members which make our efficient level drop. 
- Not wanting to train new hire even before the new hire was onboarded. One of the seniors went on a rant and decided to not be available on the week when the new hire was onboarded to avoid training them. 
- Using other colleague's name to sign off is a trend for some reason here. I've been caught in such situation multiple times and had to confront them accordingly. 
- Empowerment to make decision. Almost everything had to be checked again and again to confirm there’s no change in process. Get’s very annoying. 
- Trust is very much broken within the team which is the most annoying thing to happen. Do not always assume those who are newly hired into the team are inexperienced. It is not in your right to judge anyone who joins the team. 
- In summary, easily one of the most demoralising place to work because there's no sense of belonging or achievement here.

review_title: Good place to work if you are not career ambitious
pros: The university on general tends to offer family friendly practices.  Overall working culture is a friendly one. Compared to the other two long standing local universities where I have also worked before, the power-distance distinction between Academic and Administrative staff is generally less i.e. SMU professors tend to treat administrative colleagues more as peers and at equal standing. The HR team puts in considerable effort to create an engaging and pleasant working culture where they can.
cons: Universities tend to have very limited career development options and many staff tend to stall stagnant in one position for too long.  Even when considering internal transfers, one major hurdle is that the new potential employer will always be cautious about offending the Dean or Director of the school or office from which the staff is from.  This 'territorial' behavior is a very strong and prevalent cultural phenomena.

review_title: Unfortunately a very uninspiring, unfriendly and hierarchical workplace
pros:
1.  Central location
2.  Good benefits and medical coverage for employees, spouse and children
cons:
1.  Very strong hierarchical culture. As other reviewers already mentioned, the power distance is too high and there is a top-down approach to decision-making.
2. Isolation in the workplace. For instance, there is no lunch with colleagues, no dinners or celebrations/annual events in the department, no activities whatsoever, office doors are closed and several colleagues are not even coming to the office for many months.
3. Uninspiring for academics, as colloquia/talks from visiting speakers (even broadly related to one's field) are a rare phenomenon. 
4. Too much politics and toxic work culture.
5. No trainings and opportunities for further education.
6. A lot of bureaucracy and unnecessary administration.
7. Unclear expectations for promotion and tenure.
8. Short-term and disrespectful mentality (e.g., academics who get invited for a job interview (and may even come from the 'other end of the world' for this) do not even get a generic job rejection email, if they are not selected for the job).

My Director didnt know what he/she was doing and was extremely biased to boot! Our department lost a lot of talented staff because of the reasons above. Only those he/she favoured have stayed on.

review_title: This is one of the worst places to work in Singapore
pros: Probably the only good thing here is work life balance. Most people leave the office at 6pm. However, in return you get to feel really depressed about how hopeless this place truly is every time you go home.
cons: This is one of the worst places to work in Singapore. The current CEO is an intelligent guy, maybe because he is a professor. However, the same can't be said about many of the senior management (non-academic staff) here. Many of them are micro-managers, or ex-govt/civil service types who have never worked in a corporate job in the 21st century. Seriously don't recommend anyone to come work here unless you want to feel exasperated by the lack of human logic or you have a great desire to feel depressed every day at work.

pros:
- Opportunity to work with students, and to facilitate their development
- Some research teams seem to be doing meaningful and impactful work
- Central location
cons:
Your experience will be highly dependent on the team you’re with, and your capacity to work with all types of colleagues. There are good, kind and compassionate people; and some who are non-cooperative, toxic and aggressively competitive. I’ve worked in teams that had people (and supervisors) at extreme ends of the spectrum. Nobody really gets fired, so the good people either leave, or remain because they need the money, and then become jaded. Overall, there isn’t a consistent campus culture, other than a need to keep up hierarchies and appearances.

It’s difficult to tell if Heads are disempowered and need to wait for instructions, or if they lack vision and imagination. To give them benefit of the doubt, I would say that Senior Mgt tends to be very top-down and opaque with regard to purpose. This trickles down to the department managers on the ground who are working the closest with students. Rather often, managers need to fight for funds or take the risk on innovative ideas; and when their projects become successful, initial naysayers jump in to take credit.

Goal setting and performance auditing exercise is a farce. Funds are allocated for staff development but there seems to be a lack of interest in how best to develop staff skills. Good staff who work hard get the short stick while mediocre or toxic colleagues who politick and look good on paper move ahead.

Understandably, what is described above happens in other companies. But as educators, you’d think we could be more collaborative and conscious of the behaviour we’re modelling for our students.

review_title: Great place initially but now its an extremely toxic environment
pros: SMU's name is a strong contender within the region and beyond in the educational space so being associated with such an industry titan is fantastic. Depending on the unit you are in, you can be part of many impactful contributions  and projects for the university as a whole.  Colleagues and peers tend to be great within the right team (Fortunately I was in a team which had excellent camaraderie). The location to boot is fantastic as well.
cons: Over the last 1.5 years, the place has become a toxic environment due to certain changes at the top senior management level. Those within the Uni would have seen a slew of resignations as a clear message that the entrepreneurial spirit that embodied SMU has been lost. Within certain units, middle management heads had no clue on how to effectively run a team whilst always degrading the team.  Certain teams had extremely high turnover rates (upwards of double digits). The Heads of department are not concerned about the high turnover as they are able to fill up these positions immediately with outside hires who are favoured by these Heads.
